conclusion: The problem involves an anti-aircraft missile launched to hit an enemy aircraft flying at a constant speed and altitude.
The missile has a mass of 100 kg and is launched with a constant acceleration of 10g upwards until it reaches 5000 m.
The gas expulsion direction changes to an angle θ downward and to the right, and the missile follows a curved path to hit the aircraft.
The aircraft is flying horizontally at 20,000 m altitude.
The missile's curvilinear movement after the first phase needs to be considered.
The initial phase involves the missile being launched from the ground and accelerating uniformly upwards with a = 10g until it reaches 5000 m.
Initial velocity, u = 0 m/s; Acceleration, a = 10 * 10 = 100 m/s²; Height, h = 5000 m.
Using the equation of motion v² = u² + 2as, the final velocity v at 5000 m is calculated to be 1000 m/s upwards.
Using the equation s = ut + (1/2)at², the time taken to reach 5000 m is calculated to be 10 seconds.
The second phase starts at 5000 m, and the gas expulsion direction changes to an angle θ downward and to the right, where cosθ = 1/11.
The thrust remains constant, and it's now directed at an angle θ downward and to the right.
Resolve the acceleration into horizontal and vertical components: a_x as the horizontal acceleration and a_y as the vertical acceleration.
The net force acting on the missile is in the direction of the gas expulsion, which is at angle θ downward and to the right.
According to Newton's third law, the force exerted by the gas expulsion is downward and to the right, so the thrust (reaction force) is upward and to the left.
The angle θ is defined as the angle downward and to the right, so the thrust is at an angle θ upward and to the left.
The thrust has both horizontal and vertical components, with the horizontal component being T cosθ = T * (1/11) and the vertical component being T sinθ.
Assume the positive y-direction is upwards, and the positive x-direction is to the right.
The thrust vector is upward and to the left, opposite to the gas expulsion direction.
The thrust is in the direction opposite to the gas expulsion, upward and to the left.
